title: FEVER: a Large-scale Dataset for Fact Extraction and VERification
passage: FEVER frames fact verification as labeling a claim as supported, refuted, or not enough information based on evidence from a reference corpus (Wikipedia). The task requires providing evidence sentences for supported/refuted labels.
license_note: Short paraphrase for research dataset construction; consult publisher for full text.

title: Provenance Data Model (PROV-DM)
passage: PROV defines provenance as information about entities, activities, and agents involved in producing a thing, so that it can be assessed and trusted. Provenance is represented as structured relationships linking what was produced to how, when, and by whom.
license_note: W3C specifications are generally available for reuse under W3C terms; see spec for details.

title: Claim Decomposition in Fact Checking (general principle)
passage: An atomic claim is a minimal, self-contained proposition that can be labeled independently with a clear subject, predicate, and scope. If a statement contains multiple propositions (e.g., two different predicates or time scopes), it should be split into separate atomic claims.

title: FEVER-style label semantics (Supported / Refuted / Not Enough Information)
passage: Supported means the reference passage entails the claim as stated. Contradicted means the reference passage entails the negation or an incompatible proposition under the claimâ€™s stated scope. Insufficient means the reference corpus does not provide enough information to decide, or the claim is underspecified relative to the reference.
license_note: Project-authored text aligned to common fact-verification task definitions.

title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
passage: The book distinguishes fast, automatic, heuristic processing from slower, effortful reasoning. When attention is limited or people are under cognitive strain, reliance on quick heuristic judgments tends to increase.
license_note: Short paraphrase; consult publisher for full text.

title: Judgment under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases
passage: Classic work describing how people use heuristics to make judgments under uncertainty, which can lead to systematic biases. The paper popularized representativeness, availability, and anchoring as key heuristics.
license_note: Short paraphrase; consult publisher for full text.

title: Nudge: Improving Decisions About Health, Wealth, and Happiness
passage: The authors define choice architecture as the context in which people make decisions and argue that defaults and framing can strongly influence choices. Designing interfaces and workflows can change outcomes by making some options easier or more salient.
license_note: Short paraphrase; consult publisher for full text.

title: Human Factors and Safety-Critical Systems (general principle)
passage: In safety-critical workflows, interface design and operational procedures function as control measures: they can prevent, detect, or mitigate errors. This implies UX and workflow can be treated as first-class safety components and evaluated with measurable cost/benefit and risk-reduction metrics.

title: On the importance of scope and qualifiers in factual assertions
passage: Claim scope should be explicit: who/what the claim is about, the relevant time period, geographic or population qualifiers, and any modality (e.g., 'may', 'always'). Changing scope typically changes truth conditions and therefore changes the label.

title: Evidence requirements for claim verification (general principle)
passage: A label should be grounded by a citeable passage. If the evidence only supports a weaker/stronger statement than the claim, or supports it only under unstated assumptions, the correct label is Insufficient rather than Supported.
